Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: Basics for assessing the various types of pests and pathogens impacting forests in North America

An understanding of the lifecycle and effects of different fungal pathogens and insects through your North America. General concepts that inform preparing and conducting a field survey/assessment. And theoretical notions that inform our societal approaches to managing healthy forests.
I learned about a variety of different forest health issues from an excellent group of guest speakers.
I learned to NOT define forest health. Great introduction to the complex topic.

A familiarity with forest health issues--primarily pests and pathogens--within the U.S. The taxonomic differences between some of the different pests and pathogens, trends of invasion, a lot on prevention and the international trade/WPM pipeline. Lots on policy, philosophy, and broad-level management. Later in the course (after spring break), more on the specifics of identifying and managing different pests and pathogens. Plenty of discussion (and some specific insights into) the definitions of forest health, etc.
I was introduced to many different forest pests and pathogens.  I gained a lot of insight into just how complex forest issues are.
I gained a broad understanding of forest health issues domestically, particularly pertaining to the northeast. The emphasis was particularly on invasive pests and pathogens.
Somewhat aligned, but would have appreciated much more focus on plant species
Exceeded my expectations. The class covered a significant amount of information, but made this information accessible.

I was hoping to learn a little bit more about field identification of forest health issues and basic management applications for them. This course was great in providing overviews, but a little bit lacking in field skills.
The class could have been a bit more practical. It is a seminar so I expected discussion, but more practical management  would have made these things a little more exciting.

In some ways, I learned a lot from the class. I became much more familiar with the major insect pests and pathogens in our forests--which might help me as a forest manager. I also have better understanding of the complexities of managing and preventing these forest health issues--which allows me to speak more intelligently about them. However, I did not gain a strong ability to field-identify many of these pests and pathogens (and the ones I did learn to identify, I did so through means external to the class). I wish I'd learned more about the individuals and how to work with them (and also, identification, which seems pretty key to me). Also, I wish we'd spent more time learning about abiotic forest health issues, like air pollution and anthropogenic issues (cars, utility lines, suburban sprawl, mining).

It did not meet my expectations.  I expected to learn all about the most important forest pests and pathogens and how to manage them.  We never got any concrete information about how to react to any of these issues, only that they're here, they're important, they're growing, they will have a huge negative impact, and they're really hard to deal with.

I expected that we would go deeper into the technical aspects of forest health, such as identification of signs and symptoms in the field and lab. I also thought we would develop more skills relating to diagnosing forest health issues and developing management prescriptions. The course was pretty lacking in the technical aspect of forest health, which is a shame as it is really a technical topic.

Expectations for assignments were not well communicated, and it would be useful if all assignments and deadlines were included on the syllabus from the start.

Mark did a great job facilitating discussions, and the opportunity to have dinner with some of the guest speakers was generous and engaging.

Talbot, the other teacher, was the worst part of this course. His comments during class were arrogant, disrespectful, and did not facilitate student learning whatsoever. He also was not present at all during the end of the semester. I would highly recommend that future versions of this course bring him in for the insect ID workshop, and not again for the rest of the semester.

I would recommend spacing the presentations out over the first half of the semester. This restructuring would allow students to focus on a topic and then present on it prior to the midterm. Maybe this only occurs with insects and fungal pathogens, versus pollution, but I think it would be informative and helpful.

The guest speakers were great. I felt like I benefited a lot from hearing from experts on various forest health issues, and on being able to join the experts for dinner and talk more casually with them afterwords. A workshop or two on field identification of forest health issues would have been very useful. Our final forest health assessments ended up being very focused on invasive plant species, even though they were not a main component of the course, which felt like a bit of a mismatch. I think that a field assessment of forest health is a useful activity, but this one felt somewhat disorganized and not as effective as it could have been. The discussion portion of the class was often frustrating, and didn't feel useful. I think the course could be improved by having fewer discussions, and/or having them targeted more specifically toward topics or management scenarios. They often felt directionless, and thus not very useful.
Less discussion. We peaked 2 months into the semester.
Better insect and fungus taxonomy workshops - need more structure, more concise but comprehensive literature (e.g., taxonomies)

The strongest parts included: the trip to the USDA quarantine facility, and the weekly presenters. The weakest parts were: the overly long, not all that informative introductory classes for insects and fungi at the beginning, and then the weekly student-led discussions. I recommend: change the structure a little bit. Break each weekly 3-hour class into 2 shorter classes, one of which is a presentation (what the first half now is), the other of which is a field walk (even just in the nearby streets and arboretum, where many of these forest pests and pathogens' identification can readily be taught to students--e.g., HWA, EAB; ALB can be saved for the USDA quarantine facility; Chestnut Blight can be shown either out at the ag station or at YMF. I think the QCI forest health assessment is a really neat idea and I think there'd be a number of ways to work with this--perhaps narrow to just 1-2 landowners' properties per group, or requiring groups to head up to their properties one by one over the course of the semester? The fact sheets and 5-minute presentations were also really valuable, but I think these should have come halfway through the course, perhaps the week before a properly timed midterm, partly as a study tool. The midterm was valuable but should have happened much earlier, and the memorization of the various information (all of which is, to give Mark credit, necessary for managers) should have been woven more thoroughly into the course--e.g., on a weekly basis (field walks?).

The format of the class was not conducive to learning about this subject.  This should not be a seminar.  There should be lectures with important information and management strategies.  The guest lecturers were very interesting, but they always felt auxiliary.  If possible, a substantial field component dealing with identifying and managing these pests would also be very useful.

The course is a great introduction to the topics and terminology relating to forest health, but doesn't really deep dive into the technical aspects. It would have been good if we spent a longer amount of time discussing those technical aspects and less time talking about the philosophy and theory behind the material.

Instead of having half of every class devoted to open-forum student-led discussions, that mostly recycled the same discussed each week, we could have devoted 1.5 hours each week to a "lab" component. This could include activities in the field learning about identifying forest health issues and developing prescriptions, or looking at things in the laboratory under a microscope more in-depth. I think the fungal and insect workshops at the beginning of the semester were far too broad and not useful. It would be better to work through the information on a weekly basis, so we could really understand the identification of different pests/pathogens.
The focus of the class was on insect and fungal pests, not much on invasive plants. Each week had a guest speaker with a different expertise
Be prepared for work! But definitely take it. An invaluable class that teaches a lot about insects, fungus, forests, and our management of these topics.
It's a great way to get an overview of a number of forest health issues. If you are looking only for practical/field applications, you might not get everything you want out of it.
I would consider auditing unless you are absolutely fascinated by forest health issues.

Hopefully it won't be a seminar anymore, but if it is, I would advise against it.  You'll learn a lot about yourself, people, and stakeholders, but not much about how to effectively manage forest health issues.
This course is a good introduction to forest health issues, but don't expect to gain an in-depth understanding of the technical aspects of forest health.
